page.title: 01ECOLOGY OF SANDHEAD
page.content: Sandhead and its environs are situated on the southernmost tip of the Scottish mainland. Our block is almost as far south as Durham City, and totally south of the Anglo/Scottish border. Lying 10 kilometres south of Stranraer, the village is the centre of activity for a community supporting an agricultural area. The area is very fortunate in that it has a good record of sunshine despite its westerly situation. Couple this to the effects of the Gulf Stream and its being almost surrounded by sea and one finds winters of amiable mildness with snow being an unusual event. The village is at the head of Luce Bay, which is the last bay on the north side of the Solway Firth and pollution is rare, the beaches being clean and pleasant. The area has escaped, {SO FAR,}any but the mildest exploitation.
